Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Feasibility of estimating musculoskeletal injury risk of material handling workers with novel wearable devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project consists of three major pieces. First is the reduction of musculoskeletal injuries for manual laborers, which already affects 600,000 workers each year. This will improve the quality of life of laborers, since an injury at work affects both their work life and their personal life. Second is to reduce the high costs associated to these injuries that need to be paid by employers, and which are estimated to be $15.2bn a year. These costs challenge the competitiveness of these companies. Thirdly, the worker injuries affect employee morale, absenteeism, productivity loss and employee turnover, all of which are challenges to the efficient running of a company.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will study the feasibility of automatically evaluating the risk of musculoskeletal injury in the workplace using smart wearable devices. These injuries affect hundreds of thousands of workers per year in the US, and cost US companies more than $15bn in direct costs. This research goal depends on the achievement of two technical objectives (i) to prove that the sensors and developed algorithms can differentiate lifting events from other worker activities, and (ii) to demonstrate that the data collected by the sensors can be used to accurately predict the output of the NIOSH lifting equation, an ergonomics risk model widely accepted in industry. Estimations of the outputs of the equation performed by our device will be compared by those computed manually by a certified ergonomist. These wearable devices can quantify the risk of musculoskeletal injuries continuously over time, providing a deeper understanding of the factors that affect risk and the ability to take measures to reduce that risk before an injury occurs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to develop discrete, internet-connected wearable devices which can be worn by industrial workers, with the objective of reducing musculoskeletal injuries from activities involving lifting and material handling. These injuries are some of the most frequent workplace injuries in the US, and cost companies $15bn a year. The wearable device is mounted on the belt of the worker and contains sensors that can measure acceleration, angular velocity and small changes in height. Using these sensors we demonstrated that it was possible to:

  • Develop algorithms that can automatically detect when a worker is performing a lifting activity, and differentiate this activity from other worker activities, such as sitting, walking and standing. The sensor data was introduced into a machine learning algorithm which could classify the activity being performed by a worker, automatically detecting actual lifting events with 92% accuracy.
  • Determine if a lifting event has been performed with incorrect biomechanics. By extracting relevant metrics such as angle of back bending, angle of back twisting, squatting and other risk metrics, an algorithm was developed to determine if a lifting event could be considered ergonomically incorrect. When such an event was detected, real-time feedback was provided to the worker in the form of a vibration in order to raise awareness of the type of posture used.
  • Demonstrate that real-time feedback was able to change worker behavior. This was done by deploying the wearable device to 2 different pilot sites, the first a logistics company and the second an industrial equipment manufacturer. In the first case, workers reduced the number of high risk postures performed by 55% after only 2 weeks of feedback. At the second pilot site, a reduction of 77% of high risk postures was achieved.

This research will lead to the development of a wearable product with the ability measure high risk activity in a workplace, and reduce the injury risk by reducing at-risk behaviors and activities. Future research will be aimed at experimenting with gamification and competition in order to accelerate behavior change in the workers, and to demonstrate that the change in at-risk behaviors and activities will ultimately lead to a drop in workplace injuries.
